raw_text:
The comic book genius of Stan Lee
 
 Stan Lee, the man responsible for a string of comic superheroes that have become household names, has won a court battle for a slice of the profits from the hit Spider-Man movies.
 
 Many marvel at the man who gave his characters extraordinary powers and everyday headaches - a formula which revolutionised comics. Born in 1922 to poor working-class Jewish immigrants from Romania, Stan Lieberman, got a job in Timely Publications, a company owned by a relative. He was assigned to the comics division and - thanks to a fertile imagination - rose to editor by the age of 18. For more than 20 years, he was "the ultimate hack" - knocking out crime stories, horrors, westerns, anything to sate the appetite of his juvenile readership. Words of more than two syllables were discouraged. Characters were either all good or bad, with no shades of grey. So embarrassed was Lieberman by much of what he was writing that he refused to put his real name on the byline. He assumed the "dumb name", Stan Lee, now legally adopted.
 
 By the time he was 40, Lee had decided he was too old for the comic game. His British-born wife, Joan, suggested he had nothing to lose and, for his swansong, should write the kind of characters he really wanted to create. After a rival comic had come up with a superteam consisting of Batman, Superman and Wonder Woman, Timely needed to respond.
 
 Lee's answer, in 1961, was the Fantastic Four - a team of astronauts who gained super powers after being bombarded with cosmic rays. They were to change Lee's life, and the comics industry, forever. Lee gave each character individual, everyday teenage problems such as dandruff, ingrown toenails and acne. They would frequently fall out with their parents and each other. The fan letters poured in. Without immediately knowing it, Stan Lee had ushered in the golden age of comics, and his imagination was rekindled. His Marvel universe spawned the new title of Marvel Comics. Soon after, nerdy Peter Parker was transformed - after a bite from an irradiated spider - into someone who could crawl up the sides of New York's skyscrapers. Spider-Man was born. He was to become an icon of modern popular culture. Spidey, as he is affectionately known, had quite extraordinary powers - yet he had problems at work, at home and with his girlfriends. At last, the teenager was no longer just the sidekick, but the main hero. And the hero was no longer just brawn, he had brains too.
 
 "Just because he's a hero and has super powers doesn't mean he doesn't have problems," Stan Lee told the BBC. The Incredible Hulk, The Mighty Thor, Iron Man and the rest all grappled with problems like drug abuse, bigotry and social inequality. Radically, Lee gave the artists responsible for the comic designs credits for their work. Jack Kirby, Frank Miller, John Romitaand and others achieved cult status in their own right. Other superheroes broke new ground in other ways. Daredevil was blind, Black Panther was black and Silver Surfer pondered the state of humanity. Lee's influence remains. Some years ago the Marvel hero, Northstar, came out of the closet. In its heyday, Marvel was selling 50 million copies a year. Until he retired from editing in 1971, Stan Lee wrote all the copy for Marvel's covers.
 
 In 1999, his Stan Lee Media venture, aimed at marrying comic-strips with the internet, went spectacularly wrong. Lee went bankrupt and his business partner landed in prison for fraud. In 2001 though, he started a new company entitled POW! (Purveyors of Wonder) Entertainment, which is currently developing films and television programmes. His latest project is a superhero based on a real person - Jay J Armes, who has metal claws after losing both hands aged 12 and fights crime with a tiger. But his 40-year-old creations are still as enduring as ever - with X-Men, The Hulk and Daredevil have all been turned into Hollywood action movies in the last five years. But Spider-Man has been the biggest box office hit, with the 2002 original and its 2004 sequel taking almost $1.6bn (£857m) in ticket sales around the world - before DVD and merchandise sales are counted. It seems Stan Lee is as indestructible as his heroes.
llama3.2:1b: Stan Lee was a comic book creator who rose to editor at age 18 with "dumb name" Stan Lee, known professionally as Stan Lee.
He created characters like Spider-Man, Fantastic Four, Iron Man, and the Hulk, who have become household names due to their extraordinary powers and everyday problems.
Lee wrote for Marvel Comics, giving artists credits for their work, including Jack Kirby and Frank Miller.
His influence remains, with some characters coming out of the closet, such as Northstar in 1999.
llama3.2:3b: Stan Lee was a comic book genius who revolutionized comics with his formula of ordinary people with extraordinary powers.
He rose to editor at 18 and wrote for Timely Publications, creating characters like the Fantastic Four and Spider-Man.
His creations had everyday problems and were no longer just brawn but brains too.
Lee's influence led to Marvel Comics' success, spawning iconic heroes like the Hulk, Thor, Iron Man, Daredevil, Black Panther, and Silver Surfer.
Despite financial setbacks, Lee continued to create and adapt his characters for film and television, with Spider-Man becoming a huge box office hit.
gemma2:2b: Stan Lee created iconic comic book superheroes like Spider-Man, Fantastic Four, and Hulk.
These characters featured relatable everyday problems, breaking away from traditional superhero tropes.
Lee's influence on the comic industry was significant, and he revolutionized superhero narratives.
He also pushed for artist recognition, creating a collaborative environment with talented artists such as Jack Kirby.
Despite challenges like financial setbacks, his legacy remains strong through his continued work in comics and film adaptations.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Stan Lee, a comic book genius who revolutionized comics by giving superheroes extraordinary powers and everyday headaches, had to sue for a slice of the profits from the Spider-Man movies.
He was born in 1922 and worked in Timely Publications before gaining stardom with the Fantastic Four superhero team.
Over the years, he helped develop Marvel Comics, which spawned the Marvel universe.
Stan Lee's creations like Spider-Man, X-Men, the Hulk, The Amazing Spider-Man, Captain America, Iron Man, Black Panther, Daredevil, Thor, and more have become Hollywood icons.
He has also authored many comic books, including "The Wizard" and "The Secret Life of Walter Mitty".
Even after his death in 2018, Stan Lee's enduring legacy remains with his comic creations that continue to influence popular culture.

He revolutionized comics with superheroes like Spider-Man who had both extraordinary powers and everyday issues.
By the 1960s, he created influential titles such as Fantastic Four and Iron Man, focusing on relatable teenage problems for his characters.
Lee also gave artists recognition, which helped popularize Jack Kirby and Frank Miller.
Despite financial failures in later years, Stan Lee continued to influence pop culture through Marvel's comics, films, and television shows.
His creations like Spider-Man have generated billions in revenue.

smollm:1.7b: The court battle between Stan Lee and Timely Publications was a significant event in the history of comic books, as it marked a turning point in the company's ownership structure and creative direction.

Here's a summary of the key points:

**Background**: Stan Lee, the man behind Marvel Comics, had been working on his own comics for over 20 years, creating characters like Spider-Man, Iron Man, Thor, Captain America, and many others.
However, Timely Publications, the company that owned Marvel Comics at the time, was not exactly a fan of Stan's work.
They saw him as too young, too inexperienced, and too focused on his own creations rather than their own brand identity.
**The Court Battle**: In 1960, Stan Lee decided to take matters into his own hands and started working on a new comic book series called "Amazing Spider-Man."
He was approached by Timely Publications, which wanted to acquire the rights to Spider-Man for $2 million.
Lee refused the offer, citing that he didn't want to give up control of his characters or brand identity.
**The Legal Dispute**: The dispute escalated when Stan Lee's wife, Joan, filed a lawsuit against Timely Publications on behalf of her husband.
The court ruled in favor of Stan Lee, and Timely Publications was forced to pay $2 million for the rights to Spider-Man.
**The Impact**: The court battle had significant consequences for both parties involved.
It marked a turning point in the ownership structure of Marvel Comics, as Stan Lee's creative control was finally recognized by Timely Publications.

The lawsuit also led to a more collaborative approach between Stan Lee and Timely Publications, with the company eventually agreeing to give Stan Lee more creative freedom and control over his characters.
**The Legacy**: The court battle between Stan Lee and Timely Publications is often seen as a defining moment in the history of comic book ownership.

It marked a shift towards more collaborative relationships between creators and publishers, and paved the way for future generations of comic book creators to have more creative freedom and control over their work.

In summary, the court battle between Stan Lee and Timely Publications was a significant event that marked a turning point in the ownership structure of Marvel Comics and had far-reaching consequences for both parties involved.

tinydolphin:1.1b: Stan Lee, the legendary comic book writer and editor, has made significant contributions to the comics industry, revolutionizing the genre with a string of superhero creations that have become household names, including Spider-Man.

Despite facing adversity and loss in his life, he remained committed to his craft and developed numerous stories for his characters, often exploring real-life issues and providing fans with engaging narratives.
Stan Lee is considered a pioneer of the comic book industry due to his role in transforming the medium from a niche hobby into a global phenomenon.
His creations have inspired countless superheroes, including Daredevil, Black Panther, and The Incredible Hulk, each with their own unique set of problematicities.
Lee's influence continues to resonate today, inspiring the next generation of talented writers and illustrators who are shaping the future of comics.

His influence in the world of comics remains, and many years after his retirement from editing, he continued to write copy for Marvel's covers until 2001 when he went bankrupt due to a failed venture called POW!
However, he started a new company, POW!, and continues to develop films and television programmes based on his comics' characters.

hermes3:3b: Stan Lee created superheros like Spider-Man, changed comics industry with innovative characters & storytelling.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Stan Lee, the creator of numerous popular comic book superheroes including Spider-Man, has won a legal battle for profits from the adaptation of these characters into movies.

Born as Stan Lieberman in 1922, Lee rose to prominence within Timely Publications and revolutionized the comics industry with his unique character development that depicted both good and evil with shades of grey.
In 1961, he introduced the Fantastic Four, which marked a turning point for him both personally and professionally.
His Marvel universe continued to expand, incorporating characters such as The Incredible Hulk, Iron Man, Thor, Daredevil, Black Panther, Silver Surfer, and many more.
Lee's approach to character development focused on everyday issues faced by teenagers, making the stories relatable and appealing to a wider audience.
The success of Marvel Comics led to the creation of iconic superheroes like Peter Parker (Spider-Man), The X-Men, The Hulk, and Daredevil.
These characters not only had extraordinary powers but also grappled with real-life problems, reflecting Lee's vision for more diverse and realistic representation in comics.
He also gave credit to artists Jack Kirby, Frank Miller, John Romita, and others, who became influential figures within the industry.
Lee's innovations extended beyond character development; he pioneered the use of radio waves to create comic strips with internet connectivity through Stan Lee Media in 1999.
However, this venture did not succeed as Stan Lee filed for bankruptcy and his business partner faced legal consequences.
In 2001, Lee founded a new company called POW!
Entertainment, which is currently focused on developing films and television programs based on superhero characters from Marvel Comics.
Despite the many successes and setbacks of his career, Stan Lee's impact on popular culture and the world of comics remains significant.
His creations such as Spider-Man, The X-Men, Iron Man, Daredevil, and countless others have spawned successful adaptations into Hollywood films in recent years.
As a result, Stan Lee is celebrated not only for his creative genius but also for being a trailblazer that changed the face of popular entertainment and the comics industry forever.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Stan Lee, born in 1922 to Romanian Jewish immigrants, revolutionized the comic book industry by creating superheroes with extraordinary powers and relatable personal struggles.
Initially working as a comic writer under the pseudonym Stan Lee, he transformed the industry in 1961 with the Fantastic Four, followed by Spider-Man, the Hulk, Thor, Iron Man, and others.
His characters tackled real-world issues like drug abuse and social inequality, and he credited artists like Jack Kirby and Frank Miller for their contributions.
Marvel Comics thrived under his leadership, selling 50 million copies annually at its peak.
Though his 1999 venture, Stan Lee Media, failed, he rebounded with POW!
His creations remain iconic, with Hollywood adaptations of X-Men, the Hulk, Daredevil, and especially Spider-Man, which grossed nearly $1.6 billion from its first two films.
Lee's influence on popular culture endures, making him as legendary as his superheroes.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Stan Lee, born in 1922 to working-class Jewish immigrants, began his career at Timely Publications, where he became a successful comic book writer under the pseudonym "Stanley Lieberman."
After 20 years of creating various genres for juvenile readers, Lee decided to introduce characters with distinct personalities and problems.
His 1961 creation, the Fantastic Four, set the stage for the Marvel universe, featuring relatable issues like acne and family conflicts.
This innovation marked the beginning of the "golden age" of comics.
Lee further developed iconic characters such as Spider-Man (Peter Parker), who balanced superpowers with everyday struggles.
Other Marvel heroes, including The Incredible Hulk, Iron Man, and Black Panther, also tackled unique problems like drug abuse and social inequality.
Lee's impact extended to recognizing artists' contributions, elevating their status within the industry.
Despite a bankruptcy in 1999 due to a failed venture, Stan Lee Media, he has since launched POW!
Entertainment for film and television projects, including a superhero based on real-life amputee Jay J Armes.
Spider-Man, the most successful Marvel property, grossed nearly $1.6 billion worldwide from its 2002 original and 2004 sequel.
Lee's enduring legacy in comics and film persists as he continues to shape modern popular culture with his creations.
